channel.title: Shell on Marcos Azevedo (aka psylinux)
channel.description: Recent content in Shell on Marcos Azevedo (aka psylinux)

item.title: Cheat Sheet :: Tmux
item.description:
Working with Sessions

New Session

  • Start a New Session
1

tmux new-session
  • Or you can type
1

tmux
  • Or you can use the shorthand
1

tmux new
  • If you’re already inside the tmux
1

: new
  • Start a New Session with the name mysession
1

tmux new -s mysession : new -s mysession

Kill/Delete Sessions

  • Kill/Delete mysession
1

tmux kill-session -t mysession
  • Or you can use the shorthand
1

tmux kill-ses -t mysession
  • Kill/Delete all sessions but mysession
1

tmux kill-session -a -t mysession
  • Kill/Delete all sessions but the current session
1

tmux kill-session -a

Rename session

  • If you’re already inside the tmux
1

Ctrl + b + $

Move Between Sessions

  • Move to Previous Session // If you’re already inside the tmux
1

Ctrl + b + (
  • Move to Next Session // If you’re already inside the tmux
1

Ctrl + b + )

Attach to an Existing Session

Attach to the Last Session

1

tmux attach-session
  • Or
1

tmux attach
  • Or
1

tmux at
  • Or you can use the shorthand
1

tmux a

Attach to an Existing Session with the Name mysession

1

tmux attach-session -t mysession
  • Or
1

tmux attach -t mysession
  • Or
1

tmux at -t mysession
  • Or you can use the shorthand
1

tmux a -t mysession

Detach from Session

  • If you’re already inside the tmux
1

Ctrl + b + d

Show ALL sessions

  • Listing ALL sessions
1

tmux list-sessions
  • Or you can use the shorthand
1

tmux ls
  • If you’re already inside the tmux
1

Ctrl + b + s

Working with tmux Window

Start a new Window

  • Start a new session with the name mysession and window name mywindow
1

tmux new -s mysession -n mywindow
  • Create a new Window // If you’re already inside the tmux
1

Ctrl + b + c

Rename a Window

  • Rename current window
1

Ctrl + b + ,
  • Close the current window
1

Ctrl + b + &

Moving Between Windows

  • Previous window
1

Ctrl + b + p
  • Next window
1

Ctrl + b + n
  • Select window by number
1

Ctrl + b + 0...9

Reorder a Window

  • Swap window number 2 and 1
1

: swap-window -s 2 -t 1

Working with Panes

Toggle Panes

  • Toggle last active pane
1

Ctrl + b + ;

Split the Pane

  • Split pane vertically
1

Ctrl + b + %
  • Split pane horizontally
1

Ctrl + b + "

Moving Between Panes

  • Move the current pane to the left
1

Ctrl + b + {
  • Move the current pane t the right
1

Ctrl + b + }

Switching Between Panes

  • Switch to pane to the direction
1
2
3
4

Ctrl + b + Up
Ctrl + b + Down
Ctrl + b + Left
Ctrl + b + Right

Toggle synchronize-panes

  • Send the same command to all panes
1

: setw synchronize-panes

Toggle Between Panes

  • Toggle between pane layouts
1

Ctrl + b + <SpaceBar>
  • Switch to next pane
1

Ctrl + b + o
  • Show pane numbers (Type the number to go to that pane)
1

Ctrl + b + q

Toggle the Pane Zoom

1

Ctrl + b + z

Convert a Pane into a Window

1

Ctrl + b + !

Resize the Pane

  • Resize the current pane height
1
2

Ctrl + b + Up
Ctrl + b + Down
  • Resize the current pane width
1
2

Ctrl + b + Left
Ctrl + b + Right

Close the Pane

  • Close the Current Pane
1

Ctrl + b + x

Enter in Copy Mode (Buffer)

  • Enter in Copy Mode
1

Ctrl + b + [
  • Enter in Copy Mode and Scroll One Page Up
1

Ctrl + b + PgUp
  • Quit Mode
1

q
  • Go to Top Line
1

g
  • Go to Bottom Line
1

G

Scroll using the Keyboard Cursor (Arrows)

  • Scroll Up
1

Keyboard Up Cursor // Up
  • Scroll Down
1

Keyboard Down Cursor // Down
  • Scroll Left
1

Keyboard Left Cursor // Left
  • Scroll Right
1

Keyboard Right Cursor // Right

Scroll using the vim keys

FIRST: Remember to Set the vim keys in Buffer Mode. Go to Set the runtime tmux Options section to learn more.

item.title: Cheat Sheet :: Linux Shell Tricks
item.description:
To find the corresponding hex code

1

echo -n "&" | hexdump -C

How to redirect standard error in bash

Command Description/Purpose
command 2>filename Redirect stderr to filename
command >output 2>filename Redirect stderr to file named filename and stdout to file named output
command &> filename Redirect stderr and stdout to filename
command 2>&- Just suppress error messages. No file created. No error message displayed on screen
command 2>/dev/null Just suppress error messages.
command 2>&1 Redirect error messages to standard output. Useful in shell script when you need to forcefully display error messages on screen

Removing blank spaces and special chars

Note that we cannot just type the accent ^, instead we must use CTRL+V and then type CTRL+M.
